prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Kriddlebridle Hollow

’Tween spindledaps and dripplebound,  
'mid moon-snaggered steel so brightly drowned,  
the Tarnishedrum does gollumdeep—  
it treads the kerblind tunnel-keep.  

Snorflask whispers bounce and clack,  
each hiccupped step ricochets back,  
a skillet-ping of boot and sigh,  
a scrittle-croak that scorns the sky.  

O heed the Grimbleratchets’ teeth,  
they nip the edges, just beneath;  
they yaffle echoes into shards,  
glass flakes of sound in shadow-guards.  

Yet further where the vents wheeze cold,  
where night inks puddles into mold,  
the Tarnishedrum begins to croon  
a lantern-gong of slithered moon.  

It slurps the dark in pale green gulps,  
it strings the silence, raveling pulps;  
its tongue is thunder wrapped in cloth,  
its lungs the archways, soot and sloth.  

But braveway walkers, heart-sword drawn,  
will stomp their heels upon the dawn—  
send fizzled yelps of rev’rant light  
to splinter phantoms out of night.  

Past drain coughs and pigeon-spray,  
the exit winks with cobalt day;  
the Tarnishedrum behind them fades,  
a rust-acned ghost that daylight trades.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line present before the first stanza: "The Kriddlebridle Hollow" - yes.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanzas count = 7; stanza lines mostly 4 lines each except stanza 2 has 5 lines (clack,...sigh, croak). 6/7 stanzas have 4 lines (≈85%). Stanza count (7) is within 3-8. Meets criterion.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Check ballad meter echo of alternating longer/shorter lines with ≥2 content-word syllable difference in ≥60% stanzas. Lines vary in length but syllable difference pattern not strongly systematic or consistent like Jabberwocky’s ~8/6 alternation. At best 3-4 stanzas may partially show this. Under 60%. Likely no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme in lines 2 and 4 (or similar lines) with slant rhyme accepted. Most stanzas have some end rhyme 2/4: drowned/keep (partial), clack/sky (imperfect), teeth/beneath (perfect), cold/moon (near), gulps/cloth (no), drawn/light (near), day/trades (no). About 5/7 have acceptable rhyme. No dominant AABB. Passes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Does the final stanza echo the first stanza with ≥2 repeated content words or clear refrain? No repeated content words or phrase. Different imagery entirely. No ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition or warning similar to “Beware...” in stanza 3 about “Grimbleratchets’ teeth” nipping edges. This functions as caution to protagonist. Yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation or armament before encounter: Stanza 6 mentions “But braveway walkers, heart-sword drawn,...” indicating readiness/preparation before confrontation with phantom. Yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear meeting between protagonist and adversary: Tarnishedrum is described in multiple stanzas, but the encounter is only implied in stanza 6 (“braveway walkers,...send fizzled yelps... to splinter phantoms”), no direct encounter or confrontation scene explicitly stated. Ambiguous but some confrontation implied. Leaning yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying or resolution action present? No clear killing or triumphant resolution; phantoms splinter but Tarnishedrum just fades suggesting escape, not slaying. No decisive action.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: The final stanza’s “exit winks with cobalt day” hints at journey’s end but no jubilant acknowledgment or celebration tone. No.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Count distinct coinages: spindledaps, dripplebound, moon-snaggered, Tarnishedrum, gollumdeep, kerblind, Snorflask, scrittle-croak, Grimbleratchets, yaffle, slurps, raveling pulps, fizzled yelps, rust-acned. Easily ≥8 distinct coinages. Yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Every stanza contains ≥1 coinage: Yes, all stanzas contain at least one coined word or neologism.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Is a named non-canonical creature/entity central? Tarnishedrum is named, appears central to the setting and action as adversary. Yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts: Words like “clack,” “scrittle-croak,” “ping,” “yelps” are somewhat onomatopoeic but no strongly emphatic bursts like “snicker-snack” or “Pop!” at end of line. Only one or two mild ones. Borderline but at least 2 weak onomatopoeic words. Yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance in ≥2 stanzas beyond incidental: Examples: "spindledaps and dripplebound", "Snorflask whispers bounce and clack", “braveway walkers, heart-sword drawn,”. Clear alliteration in multiple stanzas. Yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone whimsical/playful/mythic: Tone is dark, mysterious, mythic but less playful and more eerie. Still within mythic atmosphere. Reasonable alignment. Yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact line matches of canonical poem: No lines or fragments copied verbatim from reference poem. Yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical lexicon usage ≤8 and favors new coinages: No canonical words used (no “brillig”, “slithy” etc.). Zero canonical tokens. Yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: Longer lines ≈8-9 syllables, shorter lines ≈5-7 syllables in ≥60% stanzas. Lines tend to be longer (some 10+ syllables), and the alternation pattern is less strict. Only maybe 2 or 3 stanzas close to pattern, less than 60%. No.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety across stanzas in (2,4): variety is moderate, no repeated exact end words >2 times. Passes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical overuse guard: No extremely overused content word >5 times or >8% tokens. Words are spread out among neologisms. Yes.</C21_think>

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
Beware the Dimpelledawn Fog

Beware the dimpelledawn, ye folk—  
'Twill slurple through the slatty gate;  
It gribbles leaf and post and oak  
And blizzters every garden slate.  
With foggletongue it whurp the hours,  
So gird a snoggle-sparkled cloak,  
And tuck three plippet-warming flowers  
To keep thine sniffles from theroke.

At brindle-bong it curled from nooks,  
A snorey shawl of pearly breath;  
It shivvled round our clinkered brooks,  
As silent-mouthed as fainted death.  
The mimpish roofs drip drappled grey,  
And rooks go flisking blind above;  
No clock-bell knows the peebled day;  
The milk-cans glister like a dove.

So hush, ye clompers, mind the glare:  
A stunslip stone may snare your toe.  
We sipped our scaldrum breakfast fair,  
Then stepped where snoddy lamp-lights glow.  
We jingled keys, we wurbled prayer—  
“O Wandergate, unclasp your mist!”  
We spun a sunward whirligig lure  
And gave the vapors twink a twist.

The gilver globe leapt yond the dross—  
A chortling blade of lemon flame!  
The fog went fleeing, frill and floss,  
With whiffling yelps of fading shame.  
Home then we came, all brisht and bold;  
The kettles blurted cheering steams;  
We raised a toast in scones of gold,  
And danced our boots to burbling dreams.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Beware the Dimpelledawn Fog" present before first stanza, non-empty and distinct from stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>4 stanzas total, all have 8 lines; more lines than typical quatrains of Jabberwocky; no 4-line stanzas, so fails quatrain shape criterion.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines do not alternate between longer and shorter lines visibly; most stanzas have uniform line length (~8-9 syllables); no clear alternating longer/shorter lines pattern.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Lines rhyme in pattern mostly (2,4), sometimes extended in 8-line stanzas, rhymes present but often couplets; no strict avoidance of AABB dominance since stanzas mostly use AABBCCDD rhyme schemes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>No final stanza echo of opening wording or repeated content words/phrases; no clear ring composition or refrain.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present, poem begins with "Beware the dimpelledawn, ye folk", direct warning.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation present: stanza 3 depicts preparation with "We sipped our scaldrum breakfast", "jingled keys", "wurbled prayer", "spun a sunward whirligig lure", showing planning and readiness.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation implied in stanza 4, "The fog went fleeing..."; direct meeting and struggle with fog represented metaphorically by "chortling blade of lemon flame".</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action present: the fog "went fleeing" chased by "chortling blade of lemon flame"; clear resolution of tension in stanza 4.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration present in stanza 4: "Home then we came", "raised a toast", "danced our boots", indicating jovial return and acknowledgement of victory.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Many coinages: dimpelledawn, slurple, slatty, gribbles, blizzters, foggletongue, whurp, snoggle-sparkled, plippet-warming, gird, mimpish, drappled, flisking, peebled, scaldrum, snoddy, wurbled, whirligig, gilver, brisht, blurted. More than 8 distinct invented words.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least several coinages; coinages evenly spread.</C12_think>
<C13_think>No single named creature or entity distinct from fog itself; fog is personified but no specific named creature central to action besides fog itself (not a non-canonical creature name). Fog is not a "creature" name like Sucrowock or other invented beings.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts are scarce or absent; few if any obvious examples of onomatopoeia like "snicker-snack" or "burbled"; words like "whurp" or "blurted" may be mild but not strong onomatopoeia.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Clear alliteration or consonance in at least 2 stanzas: examples include "snoggle-sparkled" cloak, "plippet-warming flowers", "chortling blade of lemon flame", "danced our boots to burbling dreams". Yes, at least 2 stanzas show alliteration/consonance.</C15_think>

<C17_think>No verbatim lines from canonical poem; all lines original.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens are absent or very few; 'whiffling' appears once, possibly 'burbling' used, but mostly new lexicon so canonical token count ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable count per line is mostly consistent: most lines around 8-9 syllables, no clear alternating short/long lines; hence does not fit Jabberwocky pattern well.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme endings vary across stanzas; couplets used but end words changed each stanza; no overuse of same rhyme ending >2 times; rhyme variety acceptable.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No excessive lexical repetition; no single content word dominates beyond threshold; vocabulary sufficiently varied.</C21_think>

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Déjàwocky Revengined

’Twas present-noon, and slithy mem’ries  
Did gimble through my braintide mill;  
All flickersome slid past yet-is,  
And wraithwords hushed the still.  

“Beware the Déjàwock, my son!  
The jaws that told, the claws once-knew!  
Beware the Echoleen, and shun  
The thricely dawning true!”  

He took his mental vorpal sense,  
So spry with question-point;  
Through neuron fens he walked far hence  
Past snapshot-swivel joint.  

No idle rest! O transient blip!  
That felt-full sight confessed—  
Eyes blinked to meet their prior script,  
And met as unmet guest.  

One two! One two! Through timewyrds thrice!  
His bodied blade went spittle-thrice;  
He left that futcrime good and sliced—  
Returned, yet nipped before.  

“And hast thou diced the Déjàwock?  
Come hither wondrous-day!”  
His grin seemed long, its echo strong;  
He’d known he’d grin this way.  

’Tis present-noon, and slithy mem’ries  
Do gimble through my braintide mill;  
O flickersome slid past yet-is—  
Same wraithwords hush the still.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the first in wording ("’Tis present-noon" / "’Twas present-noon", "slithy mem’ries" / "slithy mem’ries", "gimble", "braintide mill"/"braintide mill") with at least 2 repeated content words and close refrain effect.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition stanza present ("“Beware the Déjàwock, my son!") with warning imagery; clear caution to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation present: "He took his mental vorpal sense", "So spry with question-point", "Through neuron fens he walked", indicating readiness, planning, and resolve before confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter stanza present ("Eyes blinked to meet their prior script"), and "One two! One two! Through timewyrds thrice!" shows confrontation with adversary (Déjàwock and Echoleen). Protagonist and adversary meet.</C8_think>

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
Desire-Waltz of the Pockle-Mown

’Ware the hasty grasses, nookling green!
    The hinter-trails beckon with prrrrumple-pack glee.
Do arm ye in hushcoats with mirth for a shield,
    And whistle a zigwam-lit meddle-free.

One kweetish footfall and two—do not stop—
    A skpril-dance starts where the ditches forget,
And lumblescant cedars bow low in flop-top
    To crown thee the captain of “shan’t–yes-yet.”

Oh rumple-run roadling, unruly of root,
    Through brambles you tumble with flibberly cheer;
The pathless undoes the unpatterned commute—
    A graffle-scrib verse ‘gainst the grid-engineer!

Yet mind the sassnibble (that shadowy joke!)
    With snaggolish scurry it whispers “turn back”;
But hurkle in laughter, give board to yon yoke,
    And spinkle the slantlight along thorny track.

At gloaming you’ll bubble where meadow meets sky,
    The city-lights glimmer like candled balloon;
There butter-bright phlooms in glad scramble reply,
    They dub thee the prince of the pockle-mown tune!

Come tumpty-tum hither, let choruses ring!
    Our foot-beats have conquered that Fouler of Chart;
We pledge to no paving, we swagger and sing,
    For every desire path marches the heart.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Desire-Waltz of the Pockle-Mown" present before stanzas—yes.</C1_think>

<C3_think>Lines in stanzas generally alternate longer/shorter with notable syllable/content differences (e.g., 8–9 vs 5–7 syllables), in ≥60% stanzas—yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Most stanzas mostly rhyme on lines 2 and 4 with slant rhymes (e.g., glee/shield, stop/top, root/commute); no AABB dominance—yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening idea of conquest and resistance but no repeated phrases or ≥2 repeated content words from the first stanza—no.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early stanza 5 contains a warning "Yet mind the sassnibble (that shadowy joke!) ... 'turn back'"—admonition evident—yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist "Do arm ye in hushcoats with mirth for a shield" implying preparation for the journey—yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is no explicit enemy or creature encounter, but stanza 5 warns of sassnibble as an adversary; no direct confrontation scene—no.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive slaying or action resolving a central conflict is described—no.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Final stanza celebrates freedom and victory over the foe "Fouler of Chart" with singing and swagger, suggesting a jubilant return or celebration—yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages include: pockle-mown, nookling, prrrrumple-pack, hushcoats, zigwam-lit, skpril, lumblescant, flop-top, rumple-run, roadling, flibberly, graffle-scrib, sassnibble, snaggolish, hurkle, slantlight, butter-bright, phlooms, tumpty-tum, Fouler. Distinct coinages well above 8—yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage word—yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>No named creature or unique entity analogous to "Jabberwock" central to confrontation; sassnibble is an adversary but barely personified—no.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts like "prrrrumple-pack" and "snaggolish" are suggestive but no clear classic onomatopoeia tokens such as “snicker-snack”; at least two plausible bursts—yes.</C14_think>

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
The Glarble-Riding Conferbulance

'Twas dimliant in the boardledome,  
The murkclops glonted high;  
All slated were the chartolines,  
And the tockpens wheezed a sigh.  

“Beware the Meetlesnare, my peer,  
That snaps with quantagreed!  
The faulephyx, the vis'ram chair,  
The tickid click-palm’s heed!”  

He took his briefblade gloss in hand—  
Long time the dov’ note he sought—  
So reamed he by the Polyglot  
In search of memoplot.  

And as in deedlist thought he stood,  
The Meetlesnare, all glare,  
Through plocketing polycarbides  
Came snarfling from its lair.  

Flip, flarble! Flip, flarble! The briefblade flashed!  
It left a carbon trace—  
It sluiced the Meetlesnare apart,  
Then vanished, leaving space.  

“Has thou bewrought the snaggling beast?  
Come cherish my ROI!”  
“O briefbrave boss!” he beam-capped cried—  
A round of mints went by.  

’Tis dimliant in the boardledome,  
The murkclops glont on high;  
Our minutes ring with victofied glee—  
Till clockwinds wave goodbye.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line is present and not part of the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 7 stanzas total; 6 are quatrains (4 lines), 1 stanza has 3 lines. 6/7 ≈ 85.7% quatrain shape, total stanza count within 3–8 with one deviation => yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Majority of stanzas show some alternating longer/shorter line pattern with ≥2 content-word syllable difference (e.g., 8-9 vs 5-7) in lines; >60% stanzas alternate length => yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>In most quatrains, lines 2 and 4 rhyme (e.g., “high” / “sigh”, “peer” / “heed”, “glare” / “lair”, “trace” / “space”, “beast” / “feast” (absent), but nuanced slant rhyme used). No dominant AABB pattern; mostly ABAB or similar => yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening stanza with similar words/concepts (“dimliant in the boardledome”, “murkclops glont on high” echoing “slithy toves gyre and gimble in the wabe” and the ring framing) and repeated atmosphere; at least 2 repeated content words/phrases present => yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>First or second stanza contains a clear admonition (“Beware the Meetlesnare, my peer”) with warning about snapping and other dangers => yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows preparation (“He took his briefblade gloss in hand”, “Long time the dov’ note he sought”, “So reamed he by the Polyglot in search of memoplot”) => protagonist prepares before encounter => yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Fourth stanza shows a clear meeting/confrontation (“The Meetlesnare, all glare, … came snarfling from its lair”) => yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Fifth stanza shows decisive action and resolution (“Flip, flarble! … briefblade flashed!”, “It sluiced the Meetlesnare apart”) => decisive act slays enemy => yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Sixth stanza contains a return/celebration: “Come cherish my ROI!”, “A round of mints went by” and joyful tone => yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Counting invented coinages: dimliant, boardledome, murkclops, slates, chartolines, tockpens, Conferbulance, Meetlesnare, quantagreed, faulephyx, vis'ram, tickid, click-palm, briefblade, dov’ note, reamed, Polyglot (non-standard in this context), memoplot, deedlist, plocketing, polycarbides, snarfling, sluiced (close to real, but arguably invented usage), bewrought, snaggling, briefbrave, beam-capped, victofied, clockwinds. Clearly >8 distinct coinages => yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage word (mainly in unusual compound or invented roots in every stanza) => yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature/entity: “Meetlesnare,” a novel name, is central adversary => yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>At least two onomatopoeic bursts present: “Flip, flarble! Flip, flarble!” and “snarfling” (suggests sound), plus others like “snaggling” close to onomatopoeic feel => yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>At least two stanzas have strong alliteration/consonance (e.g., stanza 2: “faulephyx, vis’ram, tickid, click-palm’s heed”, stanza 4: “plocketing polycarbides”, “snarfling”) => yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is whimsical and playful with mythic aura, unusual coined words and surreal setting matching Jabberwocky style => yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines match the canonical poem verbatim; all lines are new constructions => yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used are minimal or none; almost all words are newly coined or normal English (like “boardledome,” “briefblade”) but no direct canonical Jabberwocky lexicon observed => fits ≤8 distinct canonical tokens => yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts suggest longer lines about 8–9 syllables and shorter about 5–7 in majority of stanzas; meets tight syllable pattern in ≥60% stanzas => yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety across stanzas: rhymes of lines 2 and 4 vary; no excessive repetition of exact rhyme words (max 2), excluding ring echo => yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No overused content word beyond limits; no single content word appears >5 times or dominates => yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show multiple distinct roots and suffixes; no single suffix dominates >50%; diverse morphologies observed => yes.</C22_think>
